question: traits

question: martyrdom

the suffering and death of a martyr.
someone (such as a teacher or parent) who goes with children on a trip or to a school dance to make sure that the children behave properly
to make a very serious or emotional request to (someone);to ask or beg for (something) in a very serious or emotional way

examples: He suffered martyrdom for his religious beliefs.

question: martyr

ans.value: to keep doing something even though it is difficult or boring
use to the limit; exhaust
thinly dispersed or scattered.
a person who is killed or who suffers greatly for a religion, cause, etc.

examples: They know that killing him will only make a martyr out of him.

question: semantics

to force someone to leave somewhere
to understand something completely, often bit difficult.
the meaning and interpretation of words, signs and sentence structure.

question: guzzle

ans.value: An expression, often found in literature, that describes a person or object by referring to something that is considered to have similar characteristics to that person or object
the way in which you express your feelings, thoughts and ideas, etc., in words
Something that is given to a person in return for something they have done, often use in a bad sense.
to drink quickly, eagerly, and usually in large amounts

examples: He guzzled his beer and ordered another.

question: snuggle

the state of having a lot of money and possessions
to ignore (someone) in a deliberate and insulting way
to lie or sit close together in a comfortable position

examples: The puppy snuggled up against the sleeping boy.

question: hysteria

ans.value: a temporary prohibition of an activity.;a delay or suspension of an activity or a law
the act of using someone unfairly for your own advantage
a situation in which many people behave or react in an extreme or uncontrolled way because of fear, anger, etc.
extremely silly or with no real meaning or importance

examples: People were in hysteria after the death of their beloved actor.
A few of the children began to scream, and soon they were all caught up in the hysteria.

question: profound

to understand something completely, often bit difficult.
to form an opinion or to make an estimate about something from known facts
very strongly felt; very great; absolute or complete

examples: I profoundly apologize.
a profound silence.
a profound thinker.

question: coerce

not clear in meaning; not thinking or expressing your thoughts clearly or precisely;
to name things separately, one by one:
to make (someone) do something by using force or threats

examples: He was coerced into signing the confession.

question: despair

causing a feeling of great surprise or wonder : causing astonishment

question: Buttress

to support, strengthen, or defend (something)
a temporary prohibition of an activity.;a delay or suspension of an activity or a law
a comparison of two things based on their being alike in some way

examples: The treaty will buttress the cause of peace.
